author: Rhys Jones
title: Massive waves flood Santa Cruz as storm surges across California coast | News | Independent TV
text: [Independent TV](/tv) Showing now | News 00:45 Massive [waves](/topic/waves) hitting the [California](/topic/california) coastline sparked evacuations on Thursday, 28 December. A high surf warning was initially issued for [Santa Cruz](/topic/santa-cruz) County as a storm brings high winds, rainfall, and a heavy tidal swell. Water can be seen pouring into the esplanade in Rio del Mar in Santa Cruz on Thursday morning as high tides flooded parking lots and streets. Evacuation orders were issued in Santa Cruz as well as across the coast as dangerously high waves pound the coastlines, expected to reach a height of 33ft. author: Miles Ruder
title: Statesville Man Arrested On Indecent Liberties Charges - WCCB Charlotte's CW
text: STATESVILLE, N.C. – A Statesville man, previously convicted for cyberstalking, is facing charges after allegedly sexually assaulting a juvenile, according to the Iredell County Sheriff’s Office. The sheriff’s office began an investigation on March 23rd after receiving a report of a man sending sexually explicit text messages to a juvenile. Officials identified the man as 61-year-old Charles Timothy Browne. Throughout the investigation, detectives said that Browne sexually assaulted the juvenile within the past year. Browne was arrested on Tuesday, April 23rd. He was charged with two counts of indecent liberties with a child and statutory sex offense against a child. Browne received a $50,000 bond for the indecent liberties charges and no bond for the statutory sex offense charge. Browne was previously sentenced to 43 months in prison in 2019 for cyberstalking. Officials said he sent over 700 threatening text messages to a female victim. He has also been arrested for trespassing, driving while impaired, and assault on a female.

author: University Communications Today
title: U of A earns recognition for student voting engagement
text:
U of A earns recognition for student voting engagement
The University of Arizona is home to one of the nation's most democratically engaged student bodies, according to the ALL IN Campus Democracy Challenge.
The U of A is one of 471 colleges and universities named to the organization's 2024 list of Most Engaged Campuses for College Student Voting, released Nov. 19. The list recognizes the colleges and universities that sought to intentionally encourage "nonpartisan democratic engagement to increase student voter engagement."
The U of A met the following criteria:
- Participated in the ALL IN Campus Democracy Challenge
- Shared 2022 National Study of Learning, Voting and Engagement (NSLVE) Reports with campus voting data with ALL IN
- Developed and submitted a 2024 nonpartisan democratic engagement action plan with ALL IN
- Listed a signatory to ALL IN's
Higher Education Presidents' Commitment to Full Student Voter Participation
The Associated Students of the University of Arizona worked throughout election season on its successful Bear Down & Vote campaign, which sought to "raise awareness, provide education and empower students to contribute positively to their community." ASUA hosted several town halls, workshops, information sessions and registration events to ensure students had access to all relevant information.
"It was a total team effort," said Adriana Grijalva, president of ASUA. "It was so inspiring to see so many fellow students engage with the democratic process and make sure their voices were heard this election season."
The ALL IN Campus Democracy Challenge "envisions a more engaged and inclusive democracy," believing that a "strong, vibrant and more representative American democracy will result from the greater inclusion of informed college student voters.
"The university is proud to support our students' civic engagement and democratic participation," said Amanda Kraus, interim vice president of Student Affairs. "The Bear Down & Vote campaign exemplifies the leadership and commitment of our student body and is a testament to their exceptional efforts to make a positive impact."

author: Agenzia Fides
title: AFRICA/SUD SUDAN - P. Luke e il suo accompagnatore vittime delle violenze intercomunitarie - Agenzia Fides
text: Juba (Agenzia Fides) – “La scomparsa di p. Luke Yugue e del suo accompagnatore va inserita nel triste contesto delle violenze intercomunitarie tra Azande e Balanda che sono di nuovo esplose dopo il grave conflitto del 2021” dice all’Agenzia Fides suor Elena Balatti, missionaria comboniana in Sud Sudan, facendo riferimento al giovane sacerdote scomparso con il suo accompagnatore, Michael Gbeko il 27 aprile, a Tombura, nello Stato dell'Equatoria occidentale. “Gli Azande sono il gruppo etnico maggioritario nell’Equatoria Occidentale mentre i Balanda sono un gruppo numericamente consistente sempre nella stessa regione ma che hanno una presenza anche nel vicino Stato del Western Bahr el Ghazal” spiega suor Elena. “Dopo anni di pacifica convivenza, nel 2021 sono emerse tensioni politiche, anche in riferimento alla delimitazione dei confini territoriali tra le due tribù; tensioni che sono sfociate in un conflitto sanguinoso, con lo sfollamento di migliaia di persone. Il conflitto si è in seguito calmato ma non è del tutto sedato, e da febbraio/marzo di quest’anno, le Nazioni Unite avevano notato un riacuirsi delle tensioni che hanno provocato, purtroppo, l’uccisione di alcune persone, nuovi sfollamenti e nuove violenze, che sono state contenute in parte dai militari” riferisce la missionaria. “La scomparsa di p. Luke si inserisce quindi in questo contesto di odio e violenza” asserisce suor Elena. “P. Luke di etnia Azande, è scomparso il 27 aprile in una zona a prevalenza etnica Balanda, dove svolgeva il suo ministero. Fin dall’inizio c’erano state illazioni sull’uccisione del sacerdote e del suo autista. Però Mons. Edward Hiiboro Kussala, Vescovo di Tombura-Yambio, aveva chiesto ai fedeli di pregare incessantemente per il ritorno dei due, e a quanto pare, ora che il Vescovo ha annunciato una preghiera funebre per entrambi (vedi Fides 23/5/2024), probabilmente ha avuto la conferma di quello che già avevano riportato alcuni media locali, che si è trattato di un duplice omicidio” dice la missionaria. Suor Elena conclude chiedendo “di pregare perché questo conflitto interetnico, che viene strumentalizzato dai politici, (in Sud Sudan siamo in un periodo preelettorale), non si rinnovi con le proporzioni delle violenza del 2021”. (L.M.) (Agenzia Fides 24/5/2024) [ASIA/INDIA - Nel Manipur che abbandona il partito di Narendra Modi non si placa la violenza interetnica](/it/news/75095) [AMERICA/COLOMBIA - Grande partecipazione ai funerali di don Ramón Arturo Montejo ucciso in una rapina](/it/news/75073)
